description: Dive into "Turin's Enchanted Castles Journey" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Turin's Enchanted Castles Journey

places.generalDescription: Castello Saffarone is an exquisite rural residence that dates back over five centuries. This charming estate remains the abode of its ancestral inhabitants, ensuring its privacy and exclusivity to the general public. Nestled in a picturesque setting, this stunning countryside haven offers a delightful ambiance coupled with delectable cuisine that is bound to impress even the most discerning palate. Its location is truly unparalleled, providing visitors with an unrivaled experience amidst breathtaking surroundings.
places.name: Castello Saffarone

reviews.text: Beautiful country home from 500+ years ago. The family still lives there. Not open to the public.

places.address: Corso Regina Margherita, 497, 10040 Torino TO, Italy

places.generalDescription: Nestled within the picturesque Parco del Valentino, Castello del Valentino is a stunning 17th-century French chateau that captures the essence of Baroque architecture. Originally commissioned by Christine of France, this enchanting castle showcases a romantic facade that feels straight out of a fairy tale. Today, it serves as the Faculty of Architecture for Turin's university, blending historical grandeur with modern education. Exploring the surrounding park and its scenic bike paths offers an opportunity to delve into Turin's rich baroque heritage.

sources.snippet: A short walk south of the historic centre, to a lovely park along the river, will bring you to the Castello del Valentino, another of the Savoy residences in Turin. There was once an ancient castle on this site but what you can see today is from the 1600s and was built as a residence for a princess. Castello del Valentino is not as large as the other palaces and has a horseshoe shape that makes it seem much more open.
sources.shortName: How to see the best palaces in Turin in 2025

sources.snippet: Built in 1620 by Duke Emmanuel Philibert of Savoy, the Valentino castle today houses the University of Architecture and isn’t open to visitors. When walking in the park, you will however be able to admire the outside facade and walk around it. The facade on the city’s side is inspired from French castles while the one overlooking the river, all in red bricks, is Italian style architecture.
sources.shortName: Visit Turin: TOP 20 Things to Do and Must See Attractions

sources.snippet: The Valentino Palace or Valentino Castle, as some people call it, was first built as a home for a princess. It is significantly smaller than other palaces in Turin, but it is nonetheless impressive in design. Its location is also superb: in the middle of Parco Valentino, or Valentino Park, one of Turin’s most beautiful parks facing the Po River.
sources.shortName: 7 Stunning Royal Palaces in Turin You Must Visit

sources.snippet: In the midst of the Giardino Pubblico del Valentino rises the Castello del Valentino, which since 1861 has been home to the R. Scuola d’ Applicazione per gl’Ingegneri. … The Castello del Valentino is one of the most distinguished buildings in the city, helping to give greater prominence to the beauty of the site on which it stands.
A charming seventeenth-century residence, set on the type of French castles of 1500. Now it houses the Faculty of Architecture. Castles, palaces and mansions
sources.shortName: Castles of Turin, palaces and mansions

places.name: Castello del Valentino

reviews.text:
The Castello del Valentino is a stunning historical landmark that beautifully combines architectural elegance with a serene riverside setting. Nestled within Valentino Park, it offers a peaceful escape from the bustle of Torino while immersing visitors in history and beauty.

The castle's exterior is a masterpiece of 17th-century design, with its elegant turrets and symmetrical layout. Although access to the interior is limited due to its use as part of the University of Torino, the surrounding grounds and gardens are worth exploring. The nearby park adds to the charm, making it a great spot for a leisurely stroll or a picnic.
We only saw it from the outside cause it was closed, but it made for some nice pics!

An amazing architectural masterpiece in the center of Turin. UNESCO heritage, it is now property of Polytechnic University of Turin - Department of Architecture and Design. It is possible to visit it only during the opening times to the public. You can check them on the official website (usually first, second and third Saturday of the month). Inside, you can find a small bar and a library.

places.address: Viale Pier Andrea Mattioli, 39, 10125 Torino TO, Italy
